author: Jason Victor Serinus
title: ‘The River’: Art against artifice
text:
‘The River’: Art against artifice Originally published October 2, 2015 at 7:00 am Ethel string quartet — violinists Corin Lee and Kip Jones, left, cellist Dorothy Lawson and Ralph Farris, viola — perform with Grammy-winning flutist Robert Mirabal at the UW’s Meany Hall on Oct. 8. “A show like this, performed by people who are committed beyond artifice and social media to really understand music through our senses, honors ceremony and art,” says Native American flute player Robert Mirabal of the collaborative work. 0 of 0 New York new music string quartet Ethel and multiple Grammy-winning New Mexican Native American flutist Robert Mirabal present a multicultural collaboration at the UW World Series. By Jason Victor Serinus Special to The Seattle Times 
“The River” resides somewhere beyond the intersection of ceremony and show biz, at a place where multicultural collaboration becomes sacred art. The work, whose world premiere takes place Thursday, Oct. 8, as part of the UW World Series, springs from a desire by the members of hip New York new music string quartet Ethel and New Mexican Native American flutist Robert Mirabal to achieve better communication between people of different cultures and worlds. 
While the official description of the work as a cross-cultural exploration of water as the embodiment of spirit and its essential role in life on Earth may sound pretty heady or ephemeral, depending upon your point of view, a chat with Ethel cellist Dorothy Lawson and the multifaceted Mirabal reveals two extremely committed artists who are deeply aware of the challenges human beings face at this critical time in history. 
Mirabal promises, on the simplest level, beautiful collaborative music that is both profound and joyful. Lawson, in turn, notes that the show has loads of dancing and singing “with a consideration of the spiritual experience that our social setting doesn’t encourage.” CONCERT PREVIEW Ethel and Robert Mirabal 
8 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 8, Meany Hall, University of Washington, Seattle; $35-$40 (206-543-4880 or uwworldseries.org ). 
Mirabal insists that the form he and Ethel have created springs from a commitment to both his ancestry and the modern world. “Not to sound New Agey or any of that, I’ve always considered my music, which comes from a 1,000-year-old culture, as a form of ceremony,” Mirabal said. Most Read Stories
